messageBody:
Hi Paul,

Excellent question!

In both situations I prefer the double-size letters. The QS manual simply says,

"Shorts and Talls stand on the same level of the 'writing-line' and keep it clearly defined. Shorts and Deeps rise to the same level of the 'upper parallel' keeping that also well defined."

I've just taken a ruler to a copy of the manual. On the page where the alphabet is introduced, the distance between the dots (indicating the height of the Shorts) is 4 mm. There is some variation in the heights of the Talls, but mostly they are around 8 mm in height. The Deeps are more consistent, dropping 4 mm below the writing line in almost every case.

I believe this is also consistent with traditional cursive writing.

If followed strictly, there is the potential for occasional contact between a Deep and a Tall on the next line, so I understand the idea of using a slightly different ratio. I'd suggest something like 1.8, though, instead of 1.5 for the medium size.

Ted


On 10/9/07, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@... > wrote:

Hi group,

I'm trying to determine how much larger the tall and deep letters are
than the small letters. It seems that the Read manual makes the large
letters double that of the smaller ones, but I'm not sure. To test
this out, I make two large representations of the letters, one in
which the large letters are about 1 1/2 times larger than the small
ones, and one in which the large ones are a full double size.

I'd appreciate as much feedback as possible to these two questions:

1. Which proportion looks the best in an ideal situation--where you
didn't have to worry about space, for example when you are doing art
work on a wall or doing calligraphy.

2. Which proportion looks better in writing? Let's pretend that you
have a nice large sheet in front of you and you know that you are
going to have to have a lot of line space for the larger letters, but
tighter space for the smaller ones.

Thanks!

Paul
